title: How many books do authors write per year? - Quora

response.answer_text: I write every day on Quora. I’ll say that on average I write about 3 pages a day (sometimes more, sometimes less.) That doesn’t seem too daunting, right? I find 3 pages a day completely manageable. Then, with the help of Melissa, my editor, I collect my answers, curate the ones I like the best and separate them out into cohesive categories. After that I publish them as books. In 2016 I published two books, “How to be Ferociously Happy” and “Amateur”.  My next book will come out in May of 2017, and then the next one after that in November 2017. I already have wrapped bundles with the contents of each one, and a file of possible titles. In other words, I am committing to this because they already exist. I intend to put out two books a year for as long as it feels right, after which I might try to do something different with my writing. I’m not sure what that will be yet, but I didn’t know about Quora two years ago and that seems to have worked out, even though I didn’t either foresee it or plan for it.

It depends on the author and genre. Many genres, like SF/F or mainstream, are not very friendly to more than two books being released per year by the same author (in traditional publishing). They feel—perhaps rightly, perhaps not!—that you may saturate your market too fast, who then move on to other authors. In romance, you can safely publish six to twelve books a year without penalty. Personally, my best speed that lets me balance work and life is four books a year. But I don’t write them all in the same genre or category. Usually it’s a mix of something in YA, something in thriller, and and something in SF/F. Or maybe just two of those, depending on how contracts fall. I can generally do two books a year in YA without a problem, but the two adult genres have a slower pace for publication. Everybody’s speed is different, and you’re not competing against other authors, so don’t peg your self-worth to how much or how fast you’re writing. Just do you.
